bibl.title: Fourteenth Biennial Report OF THE COMMANDANT OF THE Nebraska Soldiers' and Sailors' Home Burkett, Nebraska To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions FOR THE BIENNIUM ENDING NOVEMBER 30, 1914

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

p.seg: Fourteenth Biennial Report OF THE COMMANDANT OF THE Nebraska Soldiers' and Sailors' Home To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions FOR THE BIENNIUM ENDING NOVEMBER 30, 1914 Burkett, Nebraska

162 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morehead, Governor, and to the Honorable members of the Board of Com - missioners of State Institutions, Silas A. Holcomb, Howard Kennedy and Henry Gerdes. Gentlemen : I hereby submit to you a detailed report of the condi - tion and the future necessities of this institution. By care - ful study and examination you, I think, will agree with me that this report is very conservative, especially as to the future necessities of this institution. While they may ap - pear at first sight to be large, when you consider the condition the institution was in when I took charge of it, you will no doubt see the necessity of making the improve - ments that I am asking for which are, in my judgment, absolutely necessary for the welfare of the members of the institution as well as the management and a credit to the State of Nebraska.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 163 ESTIMATED EXPENSES FOR THE COMING BIENNIUM, 1915-1917 Officers' Salaries Year Biennium Commandant $1,500 $3,000 Adjutant 90O..._ 1,800 Surgeon _ 1,200 _ 2,400 Matron 500 1,000 Engineer 1,020 2,040 Night Engineer 600. 1.200 Farm Manager 600. ....'.... 1,200 Bookkeeper and Stenographer 600 1,200 $6,920 $13,840 Employees' Wages Serg. FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF 166 Col. Ferdinand Zimmerer, Commandant, Nebraska Soldiers' and Sailors' Home, Burkett, Nebraska. Dear Sir: The following report of the hospital conditions is sub - mitted herewith : During the last biennium there have been 98 deaths of members (18 more than during the preceeding one) and of these 64 were men and 34 were women. Of this number, 13 men and 9 women died while on furlough. During the first half of this biennium there were 48 deaths — 31 men and 19 women. During the last half there were 50 deaths — 33 men and 17 women of whom 7 men and 4 women died while on furlough. In the first half of this biennium there were 70 men and 36 women admitted to the hospital and in the latter half 60 men and 38 women, most of them brought from other buildings but a large number were new members of the institution. 18 members (10 men and 8 women) have been located elsewhere in the institution. There are now 35 men and 43 women in the hospital and 38 men and 16 women in the two convalescent hospitals. During the twelve months ending Dec. 1, 1914, I have attended to 7200 office calls in the dispensary and have 6600 hospital calls and 3750 calls elsewhere in the institu - tion. I have dispensed $1,000.00 worth of drugs for the year 1913-1914. All beds in the hospital are at present occupied and the total patient capacity increased over that of the first half of the biennium by fitting up two additional rooms for patients' use. The capacity of the West Hospital is taxed now and provision must be made for caring for many more who need the care of the nursing staff. Owing to the in - creasing decrepitude of the members of this Home it will

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 167 be necessary to provide one more ward for men and one more for women with nurses attending. The sanitary surroundings are greatly improved by the building of 5 large skylights and ventilators. The painting of the West Hospital has added greatly to the appearance and healthf ulness of the surroundings. The nurse force has been reorganized with a trained nurse in charge and for the nurses a uniform wage scale established. The two convalescent hospitals are very much in need of repair and painting and, if done, will greatly benefit the well being of the patients housed therein. Two more venti - lators are needed in the West Hospital and the dining rooms and kitchen as well as the second story hall painted. Some noiseless and sanitary floor covering, such as linoleum, is needed on all the hall flooring of the West Hospital. The morgue has been repaired and painted and is in charge of a man experienced in undertaking. The stock of drugs is of the best and an ample supply is kept on hand. Respectfully submitted, Dr. C. P. Fordyce. Burkett, Nebraska, November 30, 191k- STATUS OF MEMBERSHIP OF THE HOME FROM DECEMBER 1, 1912, TO NOVEMBER 30, 1914 Men present November 30, 1912 Men absent November 30, 1912 Admitted from Dec. 1, 1912, to Nov. 30, 1913 Discharged from Dec. 1, 191*. to Nov. 30. 1913 Gain for 12 months Women present November 30, 1912 Women absent November 30, 1912 Admitted from Dec. 1, 1912, to Nov. 30. 1913 Deaths, Dec. 1, 1912, to Nov. 30, 1913 Discharged from Dec. 1, 1912, to Nov. 30, 1913 Gain Deaths, Dec. 1, 1912, Nov. 30, 191S

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 187 In conclusion I wish to thank you for the co-operation and kindness and confidence you have shown towards my - self and the rest of the officers in charge of this Home. Very respectfully. Ferdinand Zimmkrkr. Commandant. Uurkett, Nebraska, November 30, 1914.
